How to Format a Manuscript in Google Docs

Formatting your manuscript properly is more than a cosmetic exercise—it's a critical part of presenting your work professionally to agents, editors, and publishers. Whether you’re writing a novel, short story, or non-fiction book, Google Docs can serve as a powerful, free tool to meet industry-standard formatting guidelines. This guide walks you through every step to ensure your manuscript is not just readable, but respected.

Why Formatting Matters

Before diving into the how, let’s address the why. Manuscript formatting helps editors and agents evaluate your writing without distraction. Sloppy layouts can suggest a lack of professionalism, no matter how brilliant your story. Proper formatting signals that you're serious, skilled, and aware of the publishing process.

Default Settings for Standard Manuscript Format

While there are variations by genre and publisher, the standard format accepted by most literary agents and contests includes the following:

  • Font: Times New Roman, 12 pt
  • Spacing: Double-spaced
  • Margins: 1 inch on all sides
  • Alignment: Left-aligned, not justified
  • Paragraph Indent: First line indent of 0.5 inch (no tabbing manually)
  • Header: Last name / Title / Page number (on every page)

Step-by-Step: Formatting a Manuscript in Google Docs

1. Set the Page Size and Margins

Go to File > Page setup and make sure the page is set to US Letter (8.5" x 11") with 1-inch margins on all sides. Click “Set as default” if you want this for future documents.

2. Choose the Right Font and Size

Select Times New Roman from the font dropdown and set the size to 12 pt. This is the most widely accepted typeface in the publishing world. Avoid stylized or hard-to-read fonts.

3. Double-Spacing

Click on Format > Line spacing > Double. This ensures adequate white space, which makes it easier for editors to write comments or edits between lines.

4. Indent Paragraphs Automatically

Rather than pressing the Tab key, use Google Docs’ ruler to set automatic indentation:

  • Click View > Show ruler if it's not visible
  • Drag the top triangle (first line indent) on the ruler to the 0.5" mark
  • This sets a standard paragraph indent

5. Insert a Header with Page Numbers

Go to Insert > Headers & footers > Header. Then, choose Insert > Page numbers. Align the header to the right and type in your last name and the manuscript title (or a shortened version).

Example: Johnson / Dark Sky / 3

6. Add a Title Page (Optional but Recommended)

Start your manuscript with a simple title page that includes:

  • Your name and contact info (top-left)
  • Word count (top-right)
  • The title of your manuscript centered in the middle of the page
  • Your name centered below the title

7. Scene Breaks and Chapter Headings

Use centered text for chapter headings, ideally written as "Chapter One," "Chapter Two," etc. For scene breaks, insert a centered # on its own line. Avoid excessive spacing or decorative symbols.

Bonus Tips for Google Docs Manuscripts

  • Use “Styles” for consistency: Modify Heading 1 for chapter titles so your document is easy to navigate.
  • Download as DOCX: Use File > Download > Microsoft Word (.docx) before submission—it’s the most accepted file format.
  • Use "Find and Replace": Clean up extra spaces or tabs globally.

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Can I submit a Google Docs file to publishers?

A: Generally no. Most publishers and agents prefer a DOCX file. You should download your formatted manuscript as a Word document before submitting.

Q: Do I need a title page for my manuscript?

A: While not always required, a title page adds professionalism and clearly identifies your manuscript and contact info. It’s highly recommended.

Q: Is Calibri or Arial acceptable for manuscripts?

A: Some editors may accept Arial, but Times New Roman is the gold standard. Calibri is often considered too casual for manuscript submissions.

Q: Should I justify text alignment?

A: No. Text should be left-aligned, not justified. Justified text creates awkward spacing, which can disrupt reading flow.

Q: Can I use italics or bold in my manuscript?

A: Italics are fine for emphasis or internal thoughts. Avoid bold, underline, or color changes. Keep formatting minimal and consistent.

Conclusion

Proper formatting is your first impression—it sets the tone before a single word is read. Google Docs gives you all the tools to format a clean, professional manuscript ready for submission. Follow these steps, double-check your layout, and give your work the polished presentation it deserves.
